context_of_use: UMD employees use the traffic simulation platform to view an interactive, real-time representation of Wonderland’s street network, traffic conditions, and environmental measurements to support informed operational and planning decisions.
scope: Wonderland Traffic Simulation and Monitoring Platform
stakeholders_and_interests: UMD employee: Wants to obtain an accurate, real-time overview of traffic and environmental conditions in Wonderland to make informed decisions.
UMD management: Wants staff to have reliable situational awareness to improve traffic management and environmental compliance.
City residents: Expect that traffic and environmental conditions are monitored so that congestion and pollution can be mitigated.
Regulatory authorities: Require monitoring of noise and air pollution levels to ensure compliance with legal limits.
description: This use case describes how a UMD employee accesses the simulation platform and views a real-time interactive map of Wonderland that displays an up-to-date street map, current traffic, traffic heat map, and real-time environmental measures including CO2 emissions, noise levels, and air pollution at overall and per-point levels.
triggering_event: A UMD employee decides to view the current real-time traffic and environmental situation in Wonderland using the simulation platform.
preconditions: The Wonderland Traffic Simulation and Monitoring Platform is operational.
The UMD employee has network access to the platform.
Sensors in Wonderland are actively providing traffic and environmental data to the platform.
The platform has an up-to-date digital street map of Wonderland, including different road types and obstacles.
The UMD employee has any required credentials or access rights to use the platform.
postconditions: The UMD employee has an up-to-date visual overview of real-time traffic conditions on the map of Wonderland.
The UMD employee can see a traffic heat map indicating crowdedness across Wonderland.
The UMD employee can see real-time environmental measurements (CO2, noise levels, air pollution levels) on the map.
The UMD employee can see overall real-time CO2 emissions and overall real-time air pollution levels for Wonderland.
The system continues to update the displayed map and data in real time while the session remains active.
assumptions: The term "simulation platform" refers to the Wonderland Traffic Simulation and Monitoring Platform specified in the scope.
Real-time data means that traffic and environmental data are updated with a delay that is operationally acceptable for monitoring but not necessarily instantaneous.
The included use case "access simulation platform" covers user authentication, authorization, and basic platform startup, and is already defined elsewhere.
The system aggregates sensor data from multiple physical sensors in Wonderland into coherent traffic and environmental indicators before visualization.
The up-to-date map, traffic data, and environmental data are already preprocessed and stored in formats directly usable by the platform for visualization.
The user interface is graphical and map-based, allowing panning and zooming of the Wonderland map, even though detailed UI behavior is outside the scope of this use case.
Noise and air pollution legal limits are defined externally and are not configured or modified within this use case.
The system continuously refreshes the displayed information without requiring the UMD employee to manually reload the page, unless explicitly requested.
Environmental measures "taken at points in the city" are associated with identifiable geographic measurement points that can be displayed as markers on the map.
Overall CO2 emissions and overall air pollution levels are presented as aggregate indicators derived from sensor data and optionally simulation models.
requirements_met: The system shall provide an up-to-date digital map of the streets of Wonderland, including different road types and obstacles, as a background for the traffic simulator.
The system shall display a real-time simulation of the current traffic situation of Wonderland on the map.
The system shall display current traffic on the map, gathered from the sensors in Wonderland, enabling monitoring of busy areas and congestions.
The system shall provide a traffic heat map that visualizes how traffic crowdedness is spread across Wonderland in real time.
The system shall display real-time environmental measures taken at points in the city on the map.
The system shall display the overall real-time CO2 emissions related to the current traffic situation.
The system shall display the real-time level of noise per measurement point on the map.
The system shall display the real-time overall level of air pollution.
The system shall display real-time levels of air pollution per measurement point on the map.
The system shall obtain real-time traffic and environmental data from sensors in Wonderland for use in the visualization.
outstanding_issues: The required maximum delay for data to still be considered real-time (e.g., seconds vs. minutes) has not been specified.
The required spatial resolution and coverage of the digital street map and measurement points have not been defined.
The exact visualization method and color scales for the traffic heat map and environmental indicators have not been specified.
Thresholds and detailed rules for highlighting areas with high congestion, excessive noise, or high pollution levels are not defined.
The required frequency and mechanism of automatic refresh for real-time data updates are not specified.
main_flow: 1. umd employee initiates access to the simulation platform → System executes the included use case "access simulation platform" and establishes an interactive session for the umd employee.
2. umd employee requests to view the real-time map of Wonderland → System loads and displays the up-to-date street map of Wonderland, including different road types and obstacles.
3. umd employee views the base map view → System overlays current traffic information on the map using data gathered from sensors in Wonderland.
4. umd employee requests visualization of traffic crowdedness → System displays a real-time traffic heat map on top of the street map, indicating crowdedness across Wonderland.
5. umd employee requests environmental information → System overlays real-time environmental measurement points on the map, showing current values at each measurement point.
6. umd employee reviews CO2 indicators → System displays the overall real-time CO2 emissions associated with the current traffic situation.
7. umd employee reviews noise indicators → System displays the real-time noise level for each measurement point on the map.
8. umd employee reviews air pollution indicators → System displays the real-time overall air pollution level for Wonderland and the real-time air pollution level per measurement point on the map.

9. umd employee continues monitoring as the situation evolves → System continuously refreshes and updates the displayed traffic, heat map, and environmental data on the map in real time for the duration of the session.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 4): umd employee chooses to temporarily hide the traffic heat map layer and focus on raw traffic data only → System hides the traffic heat map overlay while continuing to display individual current traffic information on the map; the flow continues with Step 5.

AF-2 (from Step 5): umd employee chooses to view only a subset of environmental measurement points (e.g., specific districts) → System filters the displayed environmental measurement points on the map according to the selected subset; the flow continues with Step 6.

AF-3 (from Step 8): umd employee adjusts the zoom level or map region to focus on a particular area of Wonderland → System updates the map viewport and continues to display real-time traffic, heat map (if enabled), and environmental indicators for the visible area; the flow continues with Step 9.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 1): The system cannot complete the included use case "access simulation platform" due to authentication failure or platform unavailability → System denies access or shows an error message indicating that the platform cannot be accessed; the use case terminates without displaying real-time traffic or environmental information.

EF-2 (from Step 3): Real-time traffic data from sensors is temporarily unavailable or incomplete → System displays the base street map and an explicit indication that current traffic information is unavailable or partially unavailable, and does not render missing traffic data; the use case continues with Step 4 if the umd employee still chooses to view available visualizations.

EF-3 (from Step 5): Real-time environmental measurement data from one or more measurement points is unavailable → System displays available environmental measurement points and clearly indicates which points or indicators lack current data; the use case continues with Step 6 using only the available data.

EF-4 (from Step 9): The connection between the client and the platform is interrupted during real-time monitoring → System stops updating the displayed data, indicates loss of connection to the umd employee, and attempts no further updates until connectivity is restored; the current execution of the use case ends.
information_for_steps: 1. User credentials, session token, platform URL, access rights.
2. Wonderland street map data, road type information, obstacle information, map rendering configuration.
3. Real-time traffic sensor data, traffic simulation state, vehicle density per road segment, congestion indicators.
4. Aggregated traffic intensity per map cell or segment, heat map color scale parameters, crowdedness thresholds.
5. Environmental measurement point identifiers, geographic coordinates, real-time environmental values per point.
6. Aggregated CO2 emission data, emission calculation parameters, current overall CO2 emission value.
7. Noise level data per measurement point, legal noise limit reference values, timestamp of each measurement.
8. Aggregated air pollution indicators, air pollutant concentration data per measurement point, overall air pollution index values.
9. Data refresh interval settings, latest timestamps for traffic and environmental data, session status information.
